ontology_metadata.description: Comprehensive, self-documenting ontology for managing portfolios, programs, and projects with integrated OKR, RACI, document management, change control, and platform tracking

glossary.purpose: Standardized definitions for all ontology terms to ensure consistent understanding and implementation

organization.definition: A legal entity or business unit that owns and manages portfolios, programs, and projects. The root entity in the PPM hierarchy.
organization.business_context: Organizations establish strategic objectives and allocate resources across their portfolio of investments.
organization.technical_note: Every entity in the ontology must reference a valid organization via org_id for multi-tenant data isolation.

portfolio.definition: A collection of programs, projects, and operational activities that are grouped together to facilitate effective management and achieve strategic business objectives.
portfolio.business_context: Portfolios align organizational strategy with execution and optimize resource allocation across initiatives.
portfolio.technical_note: Portfolios are the primary grouping mechanism for programs and projects, enabling strategic alignment and resource optimization.

program.definition: A group of related projects, subsidiary programs, and program activities managed in a coordinated manner to obtain benefits not available from managing them individually.
program.business_context: Programs deliver transformational change and realize strategic benefits through coordinated project delivery.
program.technical_note: Programs bridge strategic intent (portfolio) with tactical execution (projects) and focus on benefits realization.

project.definition: A temporary endeavor undertaken to create a unique product, service, or result with defined beginning and end dates, specific objectives, and constrained resources.
project.business_context: Projects are the primary execution vehicle for delivering specific outputs within time, cost, and quality constraints.
project.technical_note: Projects are the lowest level in the PPM hierarchy where actual work is performed and deliverables are produced.

stakeholder.definition: An individual, group, or organization that may affect, be affected by, or perceive itself to be affected by a decision, activity, or outcome of a portfolio, program, or project.
stakeholder.business_context: Stakeholders have varying levels of authority, interest, and influence in PPM activities and outcomes.
stakeholder.technical_note: Stakeholders are linked to PPM entities through roles and RACI assignments for clear accountability.

okr.definition: Objectives and Key Results - A goal-setting framework where Objectives define qualitative goals and Key Results measure quantitative progress toward those objectives.
okr.business_context: OKRs provide strategic alignment from organizational objectives down to project-level execution.
okr.technical_note: OKRs cascade hierarchically and link to PPM entities to enable traceability from strategy to execution.

raci.definition: Responsible, Accountable, Consulted, Informed - A responsibility assignment matrix that clarifies roles and responsibilities for activities, deliverables, and decisions.
raci.business_context: RACI ensures clear accountability and prevents confusion about roles and decision-making authority.
raci.technical_note: RACI assignments are entity-specific and activity-specific, enabling granular responsibility tracking.

milestone.definition: A significant point or event in a project, program, or portfolio timeline, typically representing completion of a major phase or deliverable.
milestone.business_context: Milestones provide progress markers and decision points for governance and stakeholder communication.
milestone.technical_note: Milestones have zero duration and represent specific points in time, unlike tasks which have duration.

deliverable.definition: Any unique and verifiable product, result, or capability to perform a service that must be produced to complete a process, phase, or project.
deliverable.business_context: Deliverables are the tangible outputs that stakeholders receive and accept as meeting requirements.
deliverable.technical_note: Deliverables have defined acceptance criteria and require formal acceptance by designated stakeholders.

risk.definition: An uncertain event or condition that, if it occurs, has a positive or negative effect on one or more objectives such as scope, schedule, cost, or quality.
risk.business_context: Risks are identified, assessed, and managed to minimize threats and maximize opportunities.
risk.technical_note: Risks are scored based on probability and impact and linked to mitigation strategies and contingency plans.

resource.definition: An asset (human, financial, technological, or physical) that can be allocated to perform work on portfolios, programs, or projects.
resource.business_context: Resources are finite and must be optimally allocated across competing demands to maximize organizational value.
resource.technical_note: Resources track capacity, allocation, cost, and availability for effective resource management.

document.definition: A structured information asset that records knowledge, decisions, plans, or results related to PPM activities, conforming to schema.org standards.
document.business_context: Documents provide evidence, guidance, and knowledge transfer for PPM activities and comply with governance requirements.
document.technical_note: Documents include rich schema.org metadata for discoverability and AI processing capabilities.

benefit.definition: An outcome of actions and behaviors that provides value to the organization, stakeholders, and beneficiaries. Benefits may be tangible (financial) or intangible (strategic, operational, customer).
benefit.business_context: Programs exist to realize benefits that justify the investment in projects and activities.
benefit.technical_note: Benefits are tracked from planning through realization with target values, actual values, and realization dates.

governance_body.definition: A formally constituted group of stakeholders with defined decision-making authority and accountability for oversight of portfolios, programs, or projects.
governance_body.business_context: Governance bodies provide direction, make key decisions, and ensure alignment with organizational objectives.
governance_body.technical_note: Governance bodies have defined membership, decision rights, and meeting schedules linked to PPM entities.

business_case.definition: A documented economic feasibility study that justifies the initiation of a portfolio, program, or project by demonstrating expected benefits exceed costs and risks are acceptable.
business_case.business_context: Business cases are decision-making tools that enable investment prioritization and approval.
business_case.technical_note: Business cases include financial analysis (ROI, NPV, payback) and are linked to specific PPM entities.

change_control.definition: A systematic approach to managing modifications to the ontology, including documentation, approval, implementation, and tracking of all changes.
change_control.business_context: Change control ensures ontology integrity, traceability, and controlled evolution while maintaining backward compatibility.
change_control.technical_note: Each change is tracked with unique identifier, timestamps, approver information, and impact assessment.

platform.definition: A software system or environment where the PPM ontology is deployed and actively used for managing portfolios, programs, and projects.
platform.business_context: Platforms represent the operational systems where PPM data and processes are executed using this ontology.
platform.technical_note: Platform tracking enables version management, deployment coordination, and impact analysis across implementations.

change_control.definition: Tracks all changes to the ontology itself, including schema modifications, entity additions, relationship changes, and version updates. Provides complete audit trail and change history.
change_control.purpose: To maintain ontology integrity, ensure proper approval workflows, track version history, and provide traceability for all ontology modifications.
business_rules: All schema changes must have a change control record
Change type must be from approved enumeration
Version numbers must follow semantic versioning
Each change must have approval before implementation

best_practices.documentation: Document rationale, impact, and migration steps for every change
best_practices.testing: Test all changes in non-production environment first
best_practices.communication: Notify all platform owners of pending changes 30+ days in advance
best_practices.versioning: Increment major version for breaking changes, minor for additions, patch for fixes

validation_rules.rule: change_type must be valid enum value
version_from and version_to must follow semantic versioning
breaking changes require approved_by to be set

change_id.description: Unique identifier for the change control record

description.description: Detailed description of what is being changed and why

is_breaking_change.description: Whether this change breaks backward compatibility

change_details.description: Detailed technical changes (schema diffs, code changes, etc.)

rollback_plan.description: Steps to rollback if change causes issues

communication_sent.description: Whether affected parties have been notified

good_examples.description: Well-documented change with complete impact assessment

data.title: Add platform tracking entity
data.description: Add new entity type 'platform' to track ontology deployments across W4M, BAIV, and AIR systems
data.rationale: Need to track which platforms are using which versions of the ontology for deployment coordination and impact analysis
data.rollback_plan: Revert to version 2.0.0 schema; no data loss as new entities are optional

good_examples.why_good: Complete documentation, clear rationale, proper versioning, impact assessment, approval workflow, platform tracking

bad_examples.why_bad: Vague title/description, no rationale, invalid change_number format, invalid change_type enum, non-semantic version numbers, breaking change without approval, no impact assessment
validation_errors: change_number format invalid - should be CR-YYYY-NNN
change_type 'update' invalid - use approved enum values
title 'Fix stuff' too vague - be specific
description 'Changed things' inadequate - explain what and why
version numbers not semantic versioning format
is_breaking_change=true but no approved_by - required for breaking changes

guidance.when_to_create: Create change control records for ANY modification to the ontology schema, entities, relationships, validation rules, or documentation. All changes must be tracked.
common_mistakes: Implementing changes without creating change record first
Not assessing impact on existing implementations
Forgetting to notify platform owners of changes
tips: Create change record in 'draft' status first
Communicate with all affected parties 30+ days for major changes
Update all platform deployments in coordinated manner
Keep change_details comprehensive for audit trail

platform.definition: Represents a software system or environment where the PPM ontology is deployed and actively used. Tracks version deployments, configuration, and status across all platforms.
platform.purpose: To manage ontology deployments, coordinate version updates, track platform-specific configurations, and ensure consistency across implementations.
business_rules: Platform name must be unique within organization
Version deployed must be a valid ontology version
Each platform must track deployment date and status
Environment must be specified (development, staging, production)
Platform can be enabled/disabled without deletion

best_practices.versioning: Keep all production platforms on same major version
best_practices.testing: Test version upgrades in development/staging before production
best_practices.monitoring: Track platform health and usage metrics

validation_rules.rule: platform_name required and unique within org
version_deployed must match existing ontology version

platform_code.description: Short code identifier (e.g., W4M, BAIV, AIR)

enabled.description: Whether platform is currently using ontology

data.description: AI-powered workflow automation and project management platform

good_examples.why_good: Complete platform information, version tracking, usage metrics, contact information, deployment history

bad_examples.why_bad: Invalid platform_id format, vague name, invalid version format, missing required fields, no org_id
validation_errors: platform_name 'System' too vague - use descriptive name
version_deployed 'latest' invalid - must be semantic version

guidance.when_to_create: Create platform records when deploying the ontology to any new system, environment, or application. Maintain accurate version tracking for all deployments.
tips: Use consistent naming convention for platforms
Track usage metrics to understand adoption
Maintain version history for audit trail

organization.definition: The root entity representing a legal entity, business unit, or organizational structure that owns and manages all PPM activities. Every other entity in the ontology must belong to an organization.
organization.purpose: To provide multi-tenant isolation, establish organizational context, and serve as the root for all PPM hierarchies.
business_rules: Every entity must reference a valid organization
Organizations can have hierarchical parent-child relationships
Strategic objectives defined at organization level cascade to portfolios

best_practices.naming: Use official legal name or recognized business unit name
best_practices.hierarchy: Model organizational structure accurately to reflect reporting lines
best_practices.objectives: Define 3-7 strategic objectives aligned with corporate strategy
best_practices.review: Update strategic objectives at least annually

validation_rules.rule: org_name must be unique within parent organization
fiscal_year_start must be valid MM-DD format

data.description: Leading provider of enterprise AI and cloud automation solutions

strategic_objectives.description: Leverage AI across all business processes to achieve 30% efficiency gain

good_examples.why_good: Complete data, clear naming, valid structure, strategic objectives defined, appropriate maturity level

bad_examples.description: Missing required fields and invalid data
bad_examples.why_bad: Invalid UUID format, empty name, invalid org_type enum, maturity level out of range (1-5), parent doesn't exist
validation_errors: org_type must be: enterprise, business_unit, department, subsidiary, joint_venture

guidance.when_to_create: Create an organization entity when establishing a new tenant, business unit, or organizational hierarchy level that will own PPM entities
common_mistakes: Using abbreviations or nicknames instead of official names
Not establishing parent-child relationships in organizational hierarchies
tips: Align strategic objectives with corporate strategy documents
Use consistent naming conventions across organization hierarchy
Review and update maturity assessments annually
Document governance framework to ensure consistency
